**(Schur’s Test)** Let $(X, \mu)$ be a measure space ($\mu$ a positive
measure). Let $K$ be a positive, measurable function on $X \times X$.
Define the operator $$\begin{aligned}
T f(x) &:= \int_X K(x,y) f(y) \,d\mu(y), x \in X\end{aligned}$$

If for some $1 < p < \infty$ there exists a measurable, strictly
positive function $h$ and a constant $M > 0$ such that $$\begin{aligned}
&\int_X K(x,y) h(y)^q \,d\mu(y) \leq M h(x)^q \\
&\int_X K(x,y) h(x)^p \,d\mu(x) \leq M h(y)^p\end{aligned}$$

with $p^{-1} + q^{-1} = 1$, then $||T|| \leq M$ in $L^p(X, d\mu)$.

Let $f \in L^p(X, d\mu)$. We have $$\begin{aligned}
|T f(x)| &\leq \int_{X} h(y) h(y)^{-1} |f(y)| K(x,y) \,d\mu(y) \end{aligned}$$

hence by Hoelder’s inequality $$\begin{aligned}
|T f(x)| &\leq \left[\int_X K(x,y) h(y)^q \,d\mu(y) \right]^{\frac{1}{q}} \left[\int_X K(x,y) h(y)^{-p} |f(y)|^p \,d\mu(y)\right]^{\frac{1}{p}}\end{aligned}$$

By the first inequality in the assumption we have $$\begin{aligned}
|T f(x)| &\leq M^{\frac{1}{q}} h(x) \left[\int_X K(x,y) h(y)^{-p} |f(y)|^p \,d\mu(y) \right]^{\frac{1}{p}}\end{aligned}$$

Evaluating $||T f||_p^p$ by Fubini and the second inequality in the
assumption we obtain $$\begin{aligned}
\int_X |T f(x)|^p \,d\mu(x) &\leq M^p \int_X |f(y)|^p \,d\mu(y)\end{aligned}$$

This completes the proof.

A noted special case is Young’s Inequality

**(Young)**

Let $K \colon \mathbb{R}^n \times \mathbb{R}^n \to \mathbb{C}$ be
Borel-measurable such that there is a constant $C > 0$ with
$$\begin{aligned}
& \sup_{x \in \mathbb{R}^n} \int_{\mathbb{R}^n} |K(x,y)| \,d\lambda^n(y) \leq C \\
& \sup_{y \in \mathbb{R}^n} \int_{\mathbb{R}^n} |K(x,y)| \,d\lambda^n(x) \leq C\end{aligned}$$

For $f \in L^p(\mathbb{R}^n)$ ($1 \leq p \leq +\infty$) define
$$\begin{aligned}
T(f)(x) &:= \int_{\mathbb{R}^n} K(x,y) f(y)\,d\lambda^n(y)\end{aligned}$$

Then $||T f||_p \leq C ||f||_p$.
